metadata.titleEn: An RFI-suppressed SMOS L-band multi-angular brightness temperature dataset (2010-2021)
metadata.description:
SMOS is the first L-band satellite that observes multi-angular brightness temperature at the globe. It’s very important for monitoring the spatial-temporal distribution of soil moisture. Due to the widespread existence of L-band radio frequency interference (RFI) and the influence of field aliasing caused by two-dimensional synthetic aperture technology, the multi-angular brightness temperatures of SMOS satellite are missing or abnormal to varying degrees. 
This data set is based on the Level-1C brightness temperature product SCLF1C officially released by ESA, which is stored in a discrete global grid (DGG) with 15-km interval and Icosahedral Snyder Equal Area projection (ISEA) projection mode. The two-step regression method proposed by Zhao et al. was used to optimize or reconstruct the multi-angular brightness temperature data affected by field aliasing and RFI. Then the refined results in DGGs were resampled to the EASE-GRID 2.0 projection (including two grid sizes of 25 km and 36 km) with hamming window approach using a footprint of 43 km.
When applying this dataset to the multi-temporal and multi-angular soil moisture retrieval algorithm, it was found that the accuracy of soil moisture inversion in this dataset is superior to other SMOS brightness temperature products in multiple soil moisture dense observation networks, especially in areas with RFI such as China, where the count of effective retrievals has significantly increased. This dataset will provide more reliable data support for the research and development of L-band land surface parameter products with long time series, such as soil moisture, freeze-thaw state, vegetation moisture, aboveground biomass, snow density, etc.
metadata.instructions:
Data file naming method: Regarding data in the projection of ISEA4H9, the file names were inherited from the SMOS SCLF1C orbit file with ascending or descending flag added to the file name. In terms of data in the projection of EASE-GRID 2.0, the file names were inherited from the file in ISEA4H9, with resample function and grid size added, for example: in the name of ”SM_REPR_MIR_SCLF1C_A_20210101T002520_20210101T011839_724_320_1_Hamming_25KM.nc”, ”Hamming” represents the resample function name, and “25KM” denotes the grid size. More details can be found in section 4.2 of the user guide. 
Usage method: Data can be read in various programming languages such as MATLAB, Python and IDL, and can also be visualized in hdfview and panoply. We provide python code (in "Code" folder) to read and plot the data file.

background: Soil moisture acts as a boundary condition for controls on land–atmosphere fluxes of energy and water, and must be accurately represented in hydrology and land surface models. The European Space Agency’s Soil Moisture Ocean Salinity (SMOS) satellite that was launched in November 2009 is the first spaceborne synthetic aperture passive microwave instrument. It relies on the new 2-D interferometry concept, and could provide global L-band brightness temperature for a range of incidence angles (from 0° to 60°) at a resolution of about 43 km. SMOS provides a unique way for measuring the moisture content at the first few centimeters of soil over land and surface salinity in the ocean. The SMOS soil moisture algorithm is primarily based on the L-band microwave emission of the biosphere (L-MEB) forward model. It uses a decision tree method to select appropriate model elements and parameters according to the auxiliary information that includes land use types. An iterative algorithm is then employed to minimize the difference between the L-MEB model simulations and SMOS multiangle observations. Several surface parameters including vegetation optical depth and soil moisture are retrieved. SMOS algorithm has produced reliable soil moisture based upon several validation studies using sparse networks or extensive field measurements. One of the issues is the uncertainty of the SMOS brightness temperature that is attributed to the radio-frequency interference (RFI) from varied sources and aliasing errors in the Fourier imaging process. Like most microwave sensors, SMOS is also susceptible to RFI, which has significantly affected the quality of brightness temperatures in some regions of the world. Another complicating factor is that the brightness temperature data from the lower look angles are less reliable due to aliasing, which is an inherent problem in interferometry. Another complicating factor when using the brightness temperature data is that the multiple incidence angle observations are not obtained at fixed values. Generally, the case within the sensitivity of the instrument is that the V-pol brightness temperature should be greater than that of the H-pol, and the V-pol brightness temperature generally increases with the incident angle while the H-pol brightness temperature decreases with the incidence angle.
research objective: The objective is to study whether it is possible to reduce the uncertainties in the SMOS brightness temperature and to develop a potential postprocessing approach that will improve the data quality and soil moisture retrieval. In this study, we present a two-step regression approach for processing/refining the SMOS L1c brightness temperature. This approach also provides a unique chance to compare the SMOS with WindSat observations over external reference targets.
challenges: Noisy data have become one of the crucial factors limiting SMOS data applications. Currently, the issue of RFI/noisy data is still a limiting factor for applications in many regions of Europe and Asia. Another complicating factor is that the brightness temperature data from the lower look angles are less reliable due to aliasing, which is an inherent problem in interferometry.
methods: In this study, we proposed a two-step regression approach that uses a mixed objective function based on SMOS L1c data products to refine characteristics of multiangular observations. The reﬁned brightness temperatures were analyzed over three external targets: Antarctic ice sheet, Amazon rainforest, and Sahara desert, by comparing with WindSat observations. The results are found to be more consistent with theoretical expectations when compared with intensive simulations based on the radiative transfer modeling. The refined brightness temperatures are verified by the implementation in soil moisture retrieval. A considerable improvement was found over two watershed networks in the United States.
dataset: Brightness temperature data at six DGG nodes (locations are shown in Fig. 3) were extracted and processed on July 1, 2010. The CA TDS L3 product is based on the Equal-Area Scalable Earth Grid with a spatial resolution of 25 km.
findings: The approach was found to be robust by validation using simulations from a radiative transfer model, and valuable in improving soil moisture estimates from SMOS. A considerable improvement was found over two watershed networks in the United States.

background: The Soil Moisture Ocean Salinity (SMOS) was the first mission providing L-band multi-angular brightness temperature (TB) at the global scale. However, radio frequency interferences (RFI) and aliasing effects degrade, when present SMOS TBs, and thus affect the retrieval of land parameters.
research objective: To alleviate this, a refined SMOS multi-angular TB dataset was generated based on a two-step regression approach.
challenges: Like other satellites, SMOS suffers from RFI contamination in certain areas of the world. Being the first L-band radiometer, problems were not expected in the protected band, so no filtering approaches were implemented in the receivers. This leads to data loss or meaningless retrievals of SMOS TBs. Great success was obtained in reducing RFI problems since the SMOS launch, but many RFI sources still need to be located, filtered, or canceled, and new RFI sources also appear every day.
methods: The ESA SMOS Level-1C Full Polarization (SCLF1C) product from 2010 to 2021 (version 724) was refined using the two-step regression approach. Firstly, TB observations at the antenna frame were filtered with various criteria. As there is no complete dataset for any epoch, a simple first-order spline interpolation was employed to fill the missing acquisitions. Then TBs at antenna level (X, Y) were converted to horizontal (H-) or vertical (V-) polarized TBs at the ground reference frame. Thirdly, a further filter procedure was applied to address potential outliers introduced during the interpolation procedure. The final procedure involves the implementation of the two-step regression approach proposed by Zhao. Following the above procedure, the refined TBs at any incidence angle ranging from 0° to 65° can be calculated with reduced RFI and aliasing effects. Various statistical metrics were computed at different steps, as illustrated in the yellow rhomboids in Fig. 1.
dataset: This RFI-suppressed SMOS TB dataset, spanning more than a decade (since 2010), is expected to provide opportunities for better retrieval of land parameters and scientific applications.
findings: The results indicate that the two-step regression refined SMOS TB may outperform CATDS RE07 TB in most cases for soil moisture retrieval because the R values (negative) between emissivity and soil moisture of refined TB are stronger compared to CATDS L3 TB, indicating a better relationship between emissivity and soil moisture. The two-step regression refined SMOS TB showed a smaller ubRMSD compared to SMAP with a value of 3.762 (3.497) K than CATDS TB with ubRMSD value of 6.81 (6.897) K at H-polarization (and V-polarization). The difference in the ubRMSD performance is primarily attributed to the RFI suppression in the refined SMOS TB, indicating its technical reliability in handling RFI-contaminated data.

background: Surface soil moisture (SM) usually refers to the soil moisture in the upper soil layer of 0 – 5 cm, and plays a key role in governing the exchanges of water and energy between the land and the atmosphere. Currently, microwave L-band radiometer is considered an appropriate tool for spatial SM mapping from space due to its strong penetration of vegetation covers and sensitivity to surface SM conditions. Launched by the ESA in 2009, SMOS was the first satellite to operate with a L-band (1.4 GHz) radiometer. Numerous validation/evaluation studies of SMOS L2/L3 SM products have been carried out during the last decade and some of them show that the SMOS L2/L3 SM products might present underestimation when compared with ground measurements. Considering the above mentioned issues, the SMOS-IC algorithm was developed by the activities funded by ESA- and CNES aiming at improving SMOS algorithms. Both the SMOS L2/L3 and SMOS-IC algorithms are based on fixed empirical/theoretical parameters of ωp eff and soil roughness. Soil roughness also affects the microwave emission of land surface, and the roughness effects vary with frequencies, angles of incidence and polarizations.
research objective: To fill this gap and further improve the performance of the SM and VOD retrievals using the SMOS data, a multi-temporal and multi-angular approach, MTMA, is proposed in this paper to systematically retrieve four parameters including VOD, SM, effective scattering albedo and surface roughness. The proposed MTMA method presented in this study is different from the SMOS and SMOS-IC algorithms in several aspects and the main ones are: (1) four parameters (vegetation optical depth VODp, effective scattering albedo ωp eff, soil surface roughness Zp s, and surface soil moisture SMp) are retrieved systematically.
challenges: The major challenge for accurate retrieval of SM is to decouple the soil and vegetation contributions, which is also the main difference between existing retrieval algorithms.
methods: In this study, a multi-temporal and multi-angular (MTMA) approach is proposed using SMOS (Soil Moisture and Ocean Salinity) satellite L-band data for retrieving vegetation optical depth (VODp, p indicates the polarization with H for horizontal and V for vertical)), effective scattering albedo (ωp eff), soil surface roughness (Zp s), and soil moisture (SMp). In this study, the refined SMOS Level 1C (SMOS L1C) and the original Level 3 (L3) TB data are applied to the MTMA algorithm for retrievals.
dataset: In this study, the refined SMOS Level 1C (SMOS L1C) and the original Level 3 (L3) TB data are applied to the MTMA algorithm for retrievals. In-situ SM data are collected from 11 SM observation networks from the International Soil Moisture Network (ISMN) and the Long-Term Agroecosystem Research (LTAR) network to verify the retrieval results of the MTMA algorithm.
findings: The MTMA VOD retrievals are found to have a reasonable global spatial distribution, which is generally consistent with the VOD retrievals obtained from the SMOS Level 3 (SMOS-L3) and SMOS-IC Version 2 (V2) (referred to as SMOS-IC), except for showing relatively lower values over densely vegetated areas compared with the other two SMOS products. The retrieved MTMA SM shows generally high correlations with in-situ measurements (11 dense observation networks) with overall correlation coefficients of > 0.75. Therefore, it is concluded that by incorporating multi-temporal SMOS data, the proposed method of MTMA can be used to systematically retrieve SM, VOD and additional surface parameters (effective scattering albedo and surface roughness) with comparable or better performance of SM than that of SMOS-IC and SMOS-L3. Moreover, this paper for the first time produced a polarization-dependent SMOS VOD product at a global scale.

background: Snow density varies spatially, temporally, and vertically within the snowpack and is the key to converting snow depth to snow water equivalent. Snow cover plays a critical role in terrestrial hydrological, climatological, and ecological processes. It influences the energy balance on the land surface, based on its high albedo and low thermal conductivity. However, when there have been multiple continental or large-scale snow depth remote sensing products, the corresponding snow density product required to convert snow depth to SWE is still limited. At a high frequency, snow volume scattering cannot be neglected. The influences of the snow depth and snow grain size on the brightness temperature (TB) are much higher than that of snow density. Therefore, to estimate snow density, the lower-frequency channel is better suited for its retrieval as it is more sensitive to snow refraction rather than snow volume scattering. The use of a fixed snow density (for example, 240 kg/m3) will result in an overestimated SWE in the early snow season and an underestimated SWE in the late snow season. In recent years, with the development of full-polarized SAR, surface and volume scattering components were extracted from different signal decomposition methods to establish empirical or physical relationships with snow density. After the launch of the Soil Moisture Ocean Salinity (SMOS) satellite for soil moisture observation purposes in November 2009, the multiple-angle L-band radiometer became an additional type of sensor applicable for snow density estimation. Preliminary studies on the physical and the practical feasibility of snow density retrieval using ground-based radiometer observations have been conducted. However, if the snow density retrieval algorithm is moved from ground-based to space-borne instruments, it will be challenged by stronger observation noise, emission from other land surface types, and the Radio Frequency Interference (RFI) from human activities.
research objective: Therefore, the scientific goal of this article is to retrieve the snow density from SMOS satellite observations, according to the theory in previous studies.
challenges: However, if the snow density retrieval algorithm is moved from ground-based to space-borne instruments, it will be challenged by stronger observation noise, emission from other land surface types, and the Radio Frequency Interference (RFI) from human activities.
methods: In this study, the snow density was retrieved using the Soil Moisture Ocean Salinity (SMOS) satellite radiometer observations at 43 stations in Quebec, Canada. We used a one-layer snow radiative transfer model and added a τ − ω vegetation model over the snow to consider the forest influence. We developed an objective method to estimate the forest parameters (τ, ω) and soil roughness (SD) from SMOS measurements during the snow-free period and applied them to estimate snow density. Prior knowledge of soil permittivity was used in the entire process, which was calculated from the Global Land Data Assimilation System (GLDAS) soil simulations using a frozen soil dielectric model.
dataset: The SMOS Level 1C (L1C) product is provided in the ISEA-4H9 grid (icosahedral Snyder equal area earth fixed) with a spatial resolution of 43 km on average. The in-situ snow measurements come from the Canadian historical Snow Water Equivalent dataset (CanSWEv3.0), which contains both the snow depth and snow water equivalent at the same station. In our study area and period, there are 43 stations with elevation < 1000 m.
findings: Results showed that the retrieved snow density had an overall root-mean-squared error (RMSE) of 83 kg/m3 for all stations, with a mean bias of 9.4 kg/m3. The remote sensing retrieved snow density outperforms the reanalysis snow density from GLDAS in terms of bias and temporal variation characteristics.

Verification.Question: Can a two-step regression approach effectively reduce the uncertainties in L-band brightness temperature data affected by radio frequency interference and aliasing?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the main challenges associated with data collection in radio frequency interference (RFI) impacted regions?
Where can researchers find datasets for validating soil moisture retrievals from satellite data?
What data collection method can be used to address the issue of radio frequency interference in multi-angular brightness temperature datasets?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to address radio frequency interference (RFI) in satellite brightness temperature datasets?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to address RFI in satellite brightness temperature datasets is the two-step regression approach applied to the SMOS Level-1C brightness temperature data. This method involves filtering TB observations at the antenna frame, interpolating missing acquisitions, converting TBs to horizontal and vertical polarizations, and applying further filters for outlier removal, ultimately refining the brightness temperatures to reduce RFI and aliasing effects.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset used in multi-temporal and multi-angular retrieval approaches for vegetation and soil moisture parameters?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset used in multi-temporal and multi-angular retrieval approaches is the refined SMOS Level 1C and the original Level 3 TB data, which are applied to the MTMA algorithm to systematically retrieve parameters such as vegetation optical depth, effective scattering albedo, soil surface roughness, and soil moisture.

Feature Specification.Question: What features should be considered when developing a postprocessing approach to enhance brightness temperature data quality for soil moisture retrieval?
Feature Specification.Answer: filtering noisy data, addressing aliasing errors, employing regression techniques, validation with theoretical models, comparison with other external observations

Feature Specification.Question: What are the essential qualities of a dataset intended for the retrieval of land surface parameters such as soil moisture and snow density from satellite observations?
Feature Specification.Answer: refined brightness temperatures, minimized noise from RFI, accurate spatial resolution, validated retrieval algorithms, comprehensive metadata about observation conditions, incidence angles, polarization

Quantification.Question: What is the spatial resolution of the refined SMOS TB dataset used for retrieving soil moisture?
How many stations in Quebec, Canada, were used to retrieve snow density using the SMOS satellite radiometer observations?

Definition.Question: What is the two-step regression approach in the context of refining satellite brightness temperature data?
Definition.Answer: The two-step regression approach is a method used to process and refine SMOS L1c brightness temperature data. It involves filtering TB observations at the antenna frame, converting them to horizontal or vertical polarized TBs at the ground reference frame, and applying further filtering to address outliers. The approach aims to reduce uncertainties such as RFI and aliasing effects, improving the data quality for soil moisture retrieval.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of the ISEA projection in storing satellite data?
Definition.Answer: The ISEA projection, or Icosahedral Snyder Equal Area projection, is a method used to store satellite data on a discrete global grid (DGG). It is significant because it allows for the equal area representation of data points, which is crucial for consistent global coverage and analysis in satellite missions like SMOS, particularly for observing variables such as soil moisture over vast geographical areas.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of RFI and aliasing affect the data quality of SMOS brightness temperatures in different regions, and how do the proposed methods address these challenges?
Comparison.Answer: RFI contamination and aliasing reduce the reliability of SMOS brightness temperatures, particularly affecting regions with high RFI sources. The two-step regression approach reduces RFI effects and improves data quality through filtering and interpolation. The MTMA approach enhances retrievals by incorporating refined data and addressing vegetation and surface roughness effects.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in data collection and processing methods between retrieving snow density using SMOS satellite observations and soil moisture retrieval in terms of handling observation noise and RFI?
Comparison.Answer: Both snow density and soil moisture retrievals using SMOS data face challenges of observation noise and RFI. For snow density, a one-layer snow radiative transfer model is used, considering forest influence and soil roughness. For soil moisture, methods like two-step regression refine brightness temperatures to reduce RFI. Both approaches use additional models and datasets to mitigate noise and improve retrieval accuracy.

Interpretation.Question: What implications do the methodological approaches used in refining SMOS datasets have for the development of new datasets aimed at retrieving land parameters such as soil moisture or snow density?
Interpretation.Answer: The methodological approaches used, such as the two-step regression and MTMA algorithms, imply that new datasets could benefit from multi-angular and multi-temporal analysis techniques. These methods enhance the accuracy of land parameter retrievals by systematically addressing noise and interference, suggesting that future datasets might continue to leverage such advanced computational techniques to improve the reliability and precision of remote sensing data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying causes that contribute to the presence of radio frequency interference (RFI) in L-band brightness temperature measurements?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The presence of radio frequency interference (RFI) in L-band brightness temperature measurements is primarily due to varied sources of interference from human activities and technical limitations. The SMOS satellite, being the first L-band radiometer, did not initially implement filtering approaches in its receivers, leading to RFI affecting data quality. Moreover, the aliasing effects in the Fourier imaging process further degrade the data quality.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why do multi-angular brightness temperature datasets face challenges in ensuring data reliability for soil moisture retrieval?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Multi-angular brightness temperature datasets face challenges in data reliability due to the inherent issues of aliasing in interferometry and the inconsistent nature of multi-incidence angle observations. Additionally, the susceptibility to RFI significantly affects brightness temperatures, particularly at lower look angles, leading to unreliable data for accurate soil moisture retrieval.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors necessitate the development of refined data processing methods like the two-step regression approach for L-band satellite data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The development of refined data processing methods like the two-step regression approach is necessitated by the need to reduce uncertainties caused by noisy data, RFI, and aliasing effects. These factors limit the applicability of SMOS data in various regions, necessitating enhanced processing techniques to improve data quality and ensure accurate retrievals of parameters such as soil moisture.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the key objectives for refining L-band brightness temperature data in the context of soil moisture retrieval?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The key objectives include reducing uncertainties in brightness temperature data by mitigating radio-frequency interference (RFI) and aliasing errors. This refinement aims to improve soil moisture retrieval accuracy and data quality, thereby enhancing the reliability of soil moisture estimates from SMOS satellite observations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in refining L-band multi-angular brightness temperature data to address radio frequency interference and aliasing effects?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedure involves using a two-step regression approach. Initially, brightness temperature (TB) observations at the antenna frame are filtered with various criteria, and missing acquisitions are filled using first-order spline interpolation. Then, TBs at the antenna level are converted to horizontal or vertical polarized TBs at the ground reference frame. A further filter is applied to address outliers introduced during interpolation. The two-step regression approach is then implemented to calculate refined TBs at any incidence angle, reducing RFI and aliasing effects.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the snow density retrieved using satellite radiometer observations, and what models are applied to account for external influences such as forest cover?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Snow density is retrieved using the SMOS satellite radiometer observations with a one-layer snow radiative transfer model combined with a τ − ω vegetation model over the snow to consider forest influence. Forest parameters and soil roughness are estimated from SMOS measurements during the snow-free period. Prior knowledge of soil permittivity is used throughout the process, derived from GLDAS soil simulations using a frozen soil dielectric model.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological strategies are employed to systematically retrieve soil moisture and vegetation parameters from L-band data, and how do they differ from existing algorithms?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A multi-temporal and multi-angular approach (MTMA) is used to systematically retrieve parameters like vegetation optical depth, effective scattering albedo, soil surface roughness, and soil moisture from SMOS L-band data. This method differs from existing algorithms by retrieving four parameters systematically and incorporating multi-temporal data, which improves performance compared to SMOS-IC and SMOS-L3 algorithms.

Enablement.Question: What techniques enable the refinement of L-band brightness temperature data to reduce radio frequency interference and improve soil moisture retrieval?
Enablement.Answer: A two-step regression approach is used to refine L-band brightness temperature data. This approach involves filtering data at the antenna frame, interpolating missing data, converting to polarized brightness temperatures, and addressing potential outliers. The refined data can be analyzed over reference targets and used to improve soil moisture retrieval by reducing RFI and aliasing effects.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of multi-angular and multi-temporal brightness temperature data enhance the retrieval of soil moisture and other land parameters?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of multi-angular and multi-temporal brightness temperature data through approaches like the MTMA allows systematic retrieval of parameters such as vegetation optical depth, effective scattering albedo, soil roughness, and soil moisture. This method enhances retrieval accuracy by leveraging the temporal and angular variability in brightness temperature observations.

Enablement.Question: What methods facilitate the assessment and mitigation of the impact of radio frequency interference on satellite-derived brightness temperature data?
Enablement.Answer: The two-step regression approach facilitates the assessment and mitigation of radio frequency interference by refining brightness temperature data through filtering, interpolation, and conversion processes. This approach has demonstrated success in reducing RFI issues, thereby enabling more reliable retrieval of soil moisture and other land parameters.

Expectation.Question: What are the anticipated challenges in using a multi-angular approach for retrieving soil moisture and vegetation parameters from satellite data, and how might these challenges affect the expected outcomes?
Expectation.Answer: The major challenge for accurate retrieval of soil moisture is to decouple the soil and vegetation contributions, which is the main difference between existing retrieval algorithms. Using multi-angular data can help address this by providing multiple perspectives of the same area, but it also requires sophisticated models to accurately interpret the data. The expected outcome is to achieve higher accuracy in soil moisture and vegetation parameter retrievals, but challenges such as radio frequency interference, aliasing effects, and noise in the data can complicate this process.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection methods in the field of SMOS brightness temperature can address the issue of radio frequency interference and aliasing?
Assertion.Answer: In the field of SMOS brightness temperature, the two-step regression approach is used to refine the data by filtering the TB observations at the antenna frame and addressing potential outliers through interpolation and conversion of TBs at antenna level to horizontal or vertical polarized TBs at the ground reference frame. This method effectively reduces radio frequency interference and aliasing effects, thereby improving data quality.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced in collecting reliable soil moisture data using SMOS satellite observations.
Assertion.Answer: The challenges in collecting reliable soil moisture data using SMOS satellite observations include dealing with noisy data due to radio frequency interference, which affects data quality in certain regions, and issues related to aliasing errors in the Fourier imaging process. These factors complicate the retrieval of accurate land parameters, especially in areas with severe RFI contamination.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore and describe the data collection methods used for acquiring multi-angular brightness temperature data in the context of mitigating radio frequency interference and aliasing effects.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods involve using the European Space Agency’s Soil Moisture Ocean Salinity (SMOS) satellite, which provides L-band brightness temperature for a range of incidence angles. A two-step regression approach is used to refine the Level-1C brightness temperature data, addressing radio frequency interference and aliasing effects. This involves filtering, interpolation, and conversion of antenna-level observations to ground reference frame, followed by further filtering procedures to mitigate outliers.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets for improving the retrieval of land parameters and discuss the strategies used to enhance data quality in the context of SMOS satellite observations.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets include the refined SMOS brightness temperature data, which spans over a decade, and is processed through a two-step regression approach to suppress radio frequency interference. Strategies to enhance data quality involve employing filtering criteria, spline interpolation for missing data, and converting antenna-level observations to horizontal or vertical polarized brightness temperatures. These refined datasets are used for better retrieval of land parameters such as soil moisture, vegetation optical depth, and snow density.
